Space Engineers is a shining example of how a game should be developed, supported, and expanded. From the moment you start building your first ship to the awe of navigating the vastness of space, the game delivers a level of freedom, creativity, and technical depth that few others come close to matching.

What truly sets Space Engineers apart is the dedication of the developers. Their continuous updates, thoughtful improvements, and genuine engagement with the community show a level of passion that’s becoming rare in the gaming industry. This is not just a game—it's a long-term project crafted with heart, shaped by player feedback, and refined over years of commitment.

The DLCs deserve special praise as well. They’re exactly what optional content should be: affordable, high-quality additions that enrich the experience without ever feeling forced. The pricing is great, the content is polished, and none of it locks essential gameplay behind a paywall. It’s refreshing to see DLCs done right.

Whether you're an engineer at heart or simply someone who loves intelligent sandbox games, Space Engineers sets the gold standard. If every game followed this model of development, transparency, and support, the gaming world would be a much better place.

Space Engineers is a game best enjoyed with friends. If you love designing ships, constructing bases, and creating complex systems with input and output connectors to load, unload, and transport materials, this game is perfect for you.

One of its strongest points is how rewarding it feels to see your engineering ideas come to life—whether you're building a massive mining vessel, a sleek fighter, or a fully automated production line. Survival mode adds real purpose to your creations, and exploring planets or space with a crew makes the whole experience even more immersive.

However, I wouldn’t strongly recommend it if you plan to play entirely solo, as the game truly shines in multiplayer and can feel a bit empty on your own. Also, if you're looking for a more polished experience with modern visuals, you might prefer to wait for Space Engineers 2, which promises improved graphics and gameplay enhancements.

Despite that, the original Space Engineers is still receiving continuous support and updates, even as the developers work on its sequel, which is impressive after so many years.

Many people here write that the game is too "complex" but I like complex games and my grudge has nothing to do with the complexity. During my short playtime I got extremely frustrated and annoyed because of three things: 
* Lack of a decent introduction
* Tedious mining tasks
* Bugs

The game starts with a very short tutorial on basically how to move around your character. After that you know nothing. How do I build stuff? What should I build? How do I get raw materials? How do I refine raw materials? I am not a fan of long tutorials, but you should add something to guide your new players to the game. It does not even need to be a tutorial, just giving the correct tools in the start might sometimes be enough to set players on the right track. Here we are stuck with a full UI and multiple pages of possible buildings etc, confusing and overwhelming you in an instant. However, this point wouldn't have been half as bad if it weren't for the next point.

Tedious mining. This is what I spent the most of my gameplay doing. Holding down my LMB to mine stone. Not even ore, stone. Maybe there is a faster way to do this, but I wouldn't know since nobody told me how to do it. To (try) and start a refinery I mined huge quantities of stone that was the refined into minuscule amounts of different resources. I had to grind my way to first create a basic refinery, in hopes of speeding up the process. Unfortunately I needed power, something I had to google my way to understand as there were no "missing power source" or other warning. I then built a windmill (since that was the cheapest power source building and I was really getting annoyed with the mining). After that I took on the slow and tedious task of build a basic assembler. And when this was finally done, we come to the last point. 
 
The windmill disappeared! It was not disassembled, it didn't tip over or something. It just disappeared. A very long grind of mining just went up in smoke!

Almost every minute in this game I spent mining and refining rocks and since you are not introduced to how the game works, you have no clue if you are even working on the correct thing. Spending 30-60 min mining and then finding out that you have to mine at the very least 30-60 min more is not fun. If you really do not want to give guidelines and want new players to simply "try things until it magically works", then you have to make that try-part easy! There are probably a lot of players who, if they read this, would be able to point out flaws in my gameplay. How I could have mined faster, done some other build order or something. I like to explore things on my own, but in this case I was given a full UI with no guidelines in such a nonchalant manner that I feel that the Space Engineers developers simply expect new players to google everything or grind. A game where you build bases, vehicles and spaceships. Then use these to search for resources, mine them. Which in turn lets you build more and bigger bases, vehicles and spaceships. I keep returning to this every few years, hoping that the game has gotten better, it never does. Instead it seems to slowly get worse. The focus seems to be on modded creative mode large scale pvp. 

The game is fun for a while when playing alone or with a friend or two, and it could have been great as a pve coop experience. Could have been, if only some work had gone into the single player, early game experience.  Its clear that this has not been the focus of the developers since release, and even then it seems after thought. There is fun to get from the sandbox, and a some fun to get from grinding through the game to space once. Unfortunately that is where it ends. Once in space its a completely blind search, at abysmally low speed at that. 


Starting in space used to work, but now its horrible. I would class it as impossible for a new player unless you get lucky or spend hours searching at random. There is no extra challenge on any of the other planets either. The difficulty is not of the fun kind where you are challenged to achieve something difficult quickly. Instead the difficulty is due to the inability to craft the needed due to grid size compatibility. You have hours to slowly realize that you must either exploit respawn mechanics, land, attack an ai ship which should be impossible since you dont have weapons, or randomly get lucky. None of which is fun or sensible. Which is such an obvious and stupid limitation is never seems more than frustrating. Its absolutely crucial to get higher max speed mods and a higher max range ore scanner mod. 

The game desperately needs better pve and more interesting survival challenges, and more interesting progression challenges. And it really could have these things. It should not be that difficult to implement either, but its just not relevant to the devs it seems. 

All pve starts are grindy, followed by an extremely slow extremely frustrating phase where you are looking for whatever ore you haven't  found yet. Followed by having nothing to do whatsoever except build, at which point you will miss a decent blueprint system, which in turn makes things grindy again. For example, it tells you to refill your hydrogen supplies from a machine, but doesn’t tell you that the machine is broken, what is wrong with it, or how you’re supposed to repair it.

It says a great deal about a tutorial that you have to look up stuff on the web to find out how you’re supposed to complete the tutorial. Also not promising was that some of the community responses I saw were toxic “you must be stupid” comments, and those useless, insulting responses were upvoted. It’s difficult for a new player to get help when a community is like that.

Another review here on Steam says there’s no tutorial. This isn’t true, there are a couple of tutorial scenarios available, but they’re easy to miss because you have to dig through the “start a new game” options a bit to find them, and they aren’t clearly labeled tutorials. 

That’s part and parcel of how bad the game is at presenting new players with essential information. There’s no dedicated “tutorial” button, and the tutorial scenarios are not the defaults, you have to scroll past play options for experienced players to find the tutorial scenarios.

I mentioned the UI. Another thing I ran into with the tutorial was that when I tried to operate machinery, I kept hitting dialogs that had absolutely nothing to do with what the machine did. I’m not sure what most of those dialogs did, but it says something that they came up first instead of essential controls.

The problem isn’t that the game is complex, it’s that it’s cryptic. Satsifactory’s a very complex game, but it’s also very good at teaching you what you need to know.

If you’re inclined to dive into this game, I strongly suggest either waiting for a free weekend to see what it’s like, or at least keep on eye on your play time so you don’t exceed the refund period.
